nodes.text: Machine learning methods can provide novel insights, more accurate analysis of accident, degradation, and survival datasets, and thereby improve decision-making and accident prevention in reliability engineering and safety applications

Machine learning taxonomy: supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, and reinforcement learning each address different data setups and tasks and form the methodological foundation for reliability and safety applications

Supervised regression and classification have been widely applied for remaining useful life (RUL) prediction, degradation modeling, fault detection, and diagnostics using models like SVR, GPR, decision trees, random forests, and deep neural networks

Unsupervised methods, especially clustering and anomaly detection, are effective for discovering patterns and early fault signatures from unlabeled sensor and operational data and have been applied to fault detection, structural damage classification, and condition monitoring

Semi-supervised learning leverages small labeled sets plus abundant unlabeled data (e.g., graph-based models, ladder networks, VAEs, co-training) to improve prognostics, RUL estimation, and fault classification when labels are scarce

Reinforcement learning, including deep and safe variants, enables sequential decision-making for inspection and maintenance scheduling and can handle large state-action spaces where classical MDP/POMDP methods become intractable
Supervised learning: regression estimates mapping fhat:X->Y for RUL and degradation (regression) and classification detects fault classes; choice of model depends on data and task

Unsupervised learning: clustering (e.g., K-means, hierarchical, SOM) partitions feature space without labels; anomaly detection (point and contextual anomalies) identifies deviations from learned normal behavior

Semi-supervised learning: uses labeled and unlabeled data under assumptions (smoothness, cluster, manifold) and methods (graph-based, S3VM, OC-SVM, deep generative) to propagate labels or learn representations
Reinforcement learning: agents learn policies via trial-and-error with reward signals; safe RL incorporates safety constraints to avoid hazardous exploration during learning

Evidence: empirical studies show ML regression/classification (SVR, GPR, DNNs, CNNs, RNNs, LSTM) improve RUL prediction, fault diagnosis, and surrogate modeling across domains (batteries, bearings, engines, turbines)

Evidence: anomaly detection and unsupervised approaches (OC-SVM, autoencoders, LSTM, CNN-based feature learning, Normal Behavior Models) have detected contextual anomalies and early faults in industrial systems and spacecraft telemetry, but often suffer high false alarm rates

Claim: Spacecraft anomaly detection poses special challenges—very high-dimensional streaming telemetry, many contextual anomalies, and operational reluctance to accept high false alarm rates—requiring scalable, precise algorithms for deployment

Claim: Deep learning (DL) architectures (CNN, RNN, LSTM, autoencoders, DBN) excel for high-dimensional, sequential, and multimodal PHM tasks and often outperform shallow methods but are computationally expensive and less interpretable

Conclusion: Promising future opportunities include (1) uncertainty quantification and deployment-aware ML, (2) fleet- and system-of-systems PHM, (3) ML integration with accident and near-miss databases and safety management systems, (4) ML combined with wearable sensors for predictive safety, and (5) adoption of advanced models (deep Gaussian processes, GANs) for better accuracy and uncertainty handling
